Hello everyone, I am Niharika. So how’s
it going? Well, in today’s lesson we are

gonna look at Binomial Pairs with the Conjunction
or a quick review on what are Binomial pairs.

Well, A binomial pair is an expression made
of two words, however its connected with a

help of a conjunction. So, either, and, or,
these are the conjunctions used to join the

two words. So in today’s lesson we are gonna
look at binomial pairs, but specifically with

the conjunction“ or”, so they are very
simple and you can use it in your daily conversation

. So let’s learn how to use it and what
exactly they mean.
So they are very easy to learn and very useful in our daily conversation, so let’s see what exactly they mean &

how you can use them. So the very first one
that I have for you here is sooner or later,

so sooner or later is an expression that you
can use for something that will surely happen.

Now we don’t know when probably there are
things that are bound to happen like death

okay sooner or later we all will die, but
that’s gonna be someday, we don’t know

you know what day or what time we will die,
but yes the death will definitely happen someday

okay so that’s how you can use this expression.
The second expression that I have for you

is more or less. So more or less is an expression
that indicates approximately 
or almost okay so for example I’ll be ready

in ten minutes more or less. So its approximately
in ten minutes you’ll be ready, so rather

than using the words like approximately or
almost you can use the expression more or

less. This project should be ready in more
or less ten days okay so probably you’re

not sure whether it’s gonna be eight days
or ten days, but you’re just giving a figure,

like an approximate figure, so you are using
this expression. The third one that I have

for you is take it or leave it, so take it
or leave it is a perfect expression used to

negotiate. It’s like your final call, so
you are not gonna negotiate further. It’s

like either you take it or leave it. This
dress is for ten dollars take it or leave

it, so you are not gonna negotiatefurther,
it’s your final offer. So when you use this

expression it’s more like a final offer
of yours. Next time you are negotiating try

using this expression and it’s simple. Then
the next one that I have for you is make or

break. Now make or break is like either it’s
a success or a failure. So nothing between

that like this football match is absolutely
make or break for Spain. Soeitherthey have

to win it or they lose then they are out of
tournament, so that’s how you can use this

expression. The fifth expression that I have
for you is win or lose, now win or lose is

pretty much similar expression to make or
break. So win or lose is again either its

success or its failure. So whether it’swin
or lose its important for him to go ahead

and start those projects or take up this opportunity.
So whether it’s gonna be successful or its

gonna be failure, it’s important for him
to start this project. So again it means that

either it’s a win or a lose situation or
either its success or failure. And then the

last phrase or the last expression that I
have for you is now or never okay now and

never is used to indicate urgency or to do
something immediately

okay so you are not gonna get another opportunity
, you have to do it now . So hey you have

to jump out of that plane, it’s like now
or never. So probably you’re in a plane

okay you’ve gone sky diving. Wow!! That’s
too much fun, so you’ve gone sky diving

and you are too terrified to jump out of the
plane. So maybe your instructor or maybe your

partner is telling you okay it’s now or
never. So you’re not gonna get another opportunity,

you gotta jump now okay on immediate basis.
So that’s how you can use this phrase. So

these are six phrases. Well, they are Binomial
pairs joined with the conjunction “or”

very simple and very easy to use. So hope
you got it and you understood it and you are

gonna use it in your conversation. I’ll
be back with a new lesson till then  you take care...
